review_title: Solid company in tough climate, but political and slow.
job_title: Product Management Director in Redwood City, CA
pros: Lot's of technology available.  As an applications person I can go shopping for what I need.  At the same time I'm not forced to use only Oracle technology, although, there are some expectations to use it.  The company is solid and is not going to disappear during tough times.  From time to time you find pockets of excellence of people that are actually innovating, but that is not the rule, rather the exception.  Some people have spent 20 years at Oracle, inconceivable to me, but true.  Good place for those with families as is not as go-go-as a startup...that can be bad too.  At the same time, ST Ventures is a great program to get innovative projects kicked off; this should be practiced and promoted throughout Oracle.
cons: Politics!!!!!!!!!!!  A lot of the politics are created by management's deliberate funding of competing projects.  This leads to people tripping each other up and scheming to take over "innovative" areas to serve their own purposes.  There are snakes in every company, but I've never seen anything like this.  Hiring can be a nightmare in the product organizations unless you are applying for Server Tech; in some cases I know of some people waiting for 4-5 months to get in...so what kind of people wait for a company for 4-5 months...probably not very good ones.  It kind of speaks to the caliber of the people at the company, doesn't it?

review_title: Huge exposure and resume value, but comes at a 'cost' that employees have to bear.
job_title: Product Management Director in Redwood City, CA
pros: market competitiveness, that translates into arguably one of the best financial performances in the industry, and gives a powerful ability to execute game changing, aggressive strategy.  in turn, this also assures a higher degree of job security, specially during times of economic stress. broad scope of business provides an exposure to the enterprise software business that very few others can match. this adds value to the resume. executive management are masters of the game, and the company makes some brilliant strategic moves. it gives employees a ringside view of an organization that is a powerful execution machine. larry ellison, all said and done, is an iconoclastic leader and brilliant strategist. in summary, the best thing about oracle is its commanding position and the way it sustains it, and for employees, the chance to be exposed to it, shape it, participate in it, learn from it.
cons: they are stingy with employee compensation, and people are expendable commodities. they are prepared to live with mediocrity in employee ranks, because the whole strategy and ethos is based on a top-down command structure, rather than bottoms-up, employee driven performance. Mid and much of senior management are all aligned to serve larry ellison's central command structure, rather than setting high bars for hiring and nurturing motivation and performance. The career planning role of HR is non-existent; they're just administrative drones. There are lots of organization silos, even duplicative functions, who all care about reporting up the command structure rather than work together. All of this also translates into the company being weak at home-grown execution, and has a lack of vision in segments that Larry Ellison is not yet convinced about.

- Flexibility - most people in product development work from home as needed. The company has enough infrastructure (vpn, remote access to dev servers, softphone, audio conference) to allow workers to be very efficient working from home
- Technology - Big, sprawling company, chances are you will find something that you like to do at Oracle. Internal transfers fairly common
- Compensation and benefits not great but competitive provided you perform well
- Company culture is very aggressive and when required can move very quickly for a company of this size. Generally very aggressive, type-A type personalities that are also smart tend to do well at Oracle.
cons:
Especially with the recent acquisition spree Oracle is now starting to look like a GE-like conglomerate. Some of my comments are specific to my organization, although I think most people in product development will have similar issues:

- Office politics is rampant. There are very few rules about anything, so most of the time mid management tends to jockey for position with senior management
- Compensation scheme has zero transparency. Titles don't matter in Oracle, there is no specific formula for granting raises, bonuses or stock options that I am aware of. It essentially boils down to how well you have done in convincing your manager that you have done a good job. There is no formal review system, each group tends to have its own system (or has no system at all). Also generally there is not enough money to go around which means in order to be well-compensated you need to be a really top performer (at least in the eye of your boss)
- No information sharing. Everything is on a need-to-know basis, there is very little downward communication from senior management. This sometimes leads to situations where even people who need to know about things are sometimes not informed, and tend to work at cross-purposes
- Release planning sometimes tends to overlook the fact that, well, people have weekends off. Release deadlines are generally unrealistic and stressful. Generally people are bullied into rather than motivated to meet deadlines.

review_title: Solid Company and Product

cons: The main downside was a fairly buggy product and a shoddy QA process although it may have improved over the past several years.  Under Moss, there were some shady senior management types but he cleared them out and the company got back on track.

review_title: Oracle  India - Need not be a resource center.
pros:
One of the few Product development companies around. Starting off as a junior engineer an employee can rise up to managerial positions fairly quickly. Opportunity to move within groups exists. Oracle India has product development, consulting, release management, technical sales, demo services, sales and many other job roles. After acquiring a host of companies, opportunity to work on many other interesting products like Essbase and Weblogic is also a possibility. 
Consulting Orgs provide opportunity to travel to different parts of the world. Oracle also provides educational benefits like tuition reimbursement. Oracle's facilities both in Hyd and Blr has a well equipped gym and a decent cafeteria.
cons:
Oracle unlike SAP or Cisco is driven out of the Headquarters. Not much scope for growth. While the growth to Sr Mgr can be quite fast ( if you are good), higher levels of growth may not happen.  SAP with its own campus also makes sure that the board visits its India offices every year. 
Cisco has made sure that senior executives in the levels of a VP are encouraged to relocate to India. This creates a culture here akin to the culture in San Jose.  Same is the case with Intel where senior managers were asked to relocate to India.

review_title: Inside Sales positions are micro-managed and rarely lead to advancement.
pros: Compensation is generally good for the industry.

In Inside Sales be prepared to be micro-managed, right down to who you called, in which specific minute of the day, how long you spoke, and what the revenue implications were that month.

review_title: More and More and More with Less and Less and Less Staff

pros: If you are good at what you are likely to survive business downturns. The company is big enough and financially well run that it is insulated from sharp fluctuations in staffing. Once you establish your reputation as a reliable employee who continually produces good work your managment is likely to allow a lot of flexibility (work from home, childcare emergencies, doctor appointments) However the work has to get done regardless of the flexibility.  And there is always way to much work to get done.
cons: It's a tough place -- there is always more work to do than is possible to get done by the individual contributor staff. 50 hour work weeks are the average. Product Development is middle and upper-middle management heavy, so there always seem to be a lot of management telling a few people to get the work done in a unreasonable amounts of time.  You are expected to be 'always on', early meetings, late meetings with India, on chat, available by desk or cell phone.  Bonuses have gotten smaller and smaller until they have almost disappeared and less and less employees get stock options. Oracle employees are often laid off to make room for the employees from the many companies we acquire. Career advancement is restrictive, we already have too many managers and they do not have a good path for individual contributors to continue to advance

review_title: Great job, fun teammates, unfair compensation, mgmt cares less to keep good people
pros:
Working at Oracle was by far the best job and team that I have ever had and I probably never will find better.  The problem though is the management refuses to adjust pay regardless of personal drive, training, dedication, performance, or personal financial hardship.  In the end, I could not afford to stay and work for 70-80% of my market worth so I had to move on.  Miss the job and the team but definitely not the paycheck.

Pluses:

Low Stress
Slow Pace 
Great Team
Line managers in HQ were honest, nice, genuine people but their hands were tied and they had little more authority than approving timecards and basic expense reports.
Expensed dinners
Expensed cel phone and home internet.
Home VOIP phone line.
Hourly pay in industry that's mainly salary.
Outstanding health plans
cons:
I can sum it up simply.  I loved my job and teammates at Oracle but was forced to leave because, after 6 years, my base pay was bottom 10% of the market per salary.com.  With aggressive OT leverage, I got up to 80% of my market worth but was seen as a bad person who was abusing the system for not settling for 60% of my market worth.  
Also, I promoted up from within but was trained in a very pigeon-holed manner by design to prevent me from being too marketable on the outside.  There was no reason for this though because our team as a whole covered most of the bases that most other companies would expect each individual to know.  When I left, I literally had to change career paths within the industry because going for the same job title ended with a never ending trail of closed doors and failed interviews.

review_title: I got to work on some really interesting things and had some great customers, but I was just a number.
job_title: Director, Product Management in Amarillo, TX
pros:
Steady financial results through tough economic times.  Lots of momentum leading to job security.  Good pay and benefits.  Good exposure to lots of customers, and your work as a product manager affects so many people, you get a following.  

Lots of the people I worked with were top-notch.  Many domains in the company are world class, such as sales execution, many parts of IT such as BI, and some of the development teams.

When I was acquired by Oracle, I expected horrifying politics because of stories I'd heard through the years.  At my level, this was not the case - I found the politics to be pretty average.

Lots of flexibility to telecommute.

People in the outside world respect the brand.
cons:
Not a people-oriented company.  They would have been happy for me to stay in the same job until I retire.  The people making staffing decisions were so many levels up, they didn't really know what I did.  They hired somebody from outside the company to do the next exciting project that had been promised to me by my direct management - that's why I finally left.

As a product manager, you don't get to work on the roadmap. All product direction and business planning is done by Thomas Kurian at the EVP level and passed down to you.  There are ways to influence things indirectly, but you have to really work your network.

This is a truly international company, and acquired teams are left geographically where there were when they were acquired.  Those are good things, but the con for many people is that you rarely have face-to-face contact with many of your peers.  Like many tech companies, you have early morning and late evening calls around the world that disrupt your home life.

This is a huge company, so things move slowly and there is lots of overhead.  You will get to work with lots of customers, but you will not get much done in development.   I got more done the first year at my next job than I did in 4 years at Oracle.

I would still recommend this company to somebody who is interested in a very stable job and good benefits, but not to somebody who wants to change the world.  More than at other companies, you have to actively work the system if you want to keep growing your skills and get new opportunities, and you have less control over your tasks and destiny.

review_title: Experience in Oracle India -Sr. QA.
pros:
1. Work Life balance. Not much work pressure and flexible timings.
2. Work from home option.This depends on the team you work in.I have seen teams where team members worked from home for weeks at a time without any problems.
3.Job security,though once in a while small layoffs happen,but,it's all hush hush and you won't hear anything about it unless it's someone you know who got laid off.
cons:
1. No Salary hikes or,yearly bonus at all. I personally had the best possible performance ratings in my performance reviews yet didn't receive a single cent of bonus or, a single cent increase in my salary in the 3+ years I spent working there. Knew quite a few people who left the organisation after 4-5 years of working there cause of no salary hikes /bonus or,minimal salary hikes of 1-3% in all the years they worked there.

2. No career growth. Just like a stagnant salary,your career growth also stagnates. If you don't run after your managers and request them to get you promoted,you will most likely stay in the same designation until they finally give it you on "seniority basis" years down the line. Performance apparently isn't a factor in promotions in Oracle India. 
Good at buttering up your managers and blowing your own trumpet is one of the two factors which may help in getting you promoted,the other being - which part of the country you are from.

3. Regionalism is quite evident. I have heard senior members in teams tell people they referred for jobs in Oracle that they needn't worry about getting hired cause  so and so director was from the same state/part of the country as the guy doing the referral and hence wouldn't reject anyone he referred.
Regionalism also shows up when it comes to hikes,bonuses and promotions.

4. No compensatory days off or,extra money if you work weekends or,holidays.

5.Middle management in some departments seem absolutely clueless on how to go about some work related activities and this often led to haphazard planning of work activities.

6.HR doesn't seem to exist in the company. You will hear and talk to HR only on the day you join and the day you quit and leave.

review_title: Great Products and Brand...... a lot more not so great

pros: Brand, Products, Opens doors, Benefit system
cons:
The ability to WFH and flexible office locations/hotdesks -  great in small doses but when everyone of your team chooses to WFH 90% of the time and don't really have a local office you do not have a team! I could easily go 2 weeks+ of heading into the Head office in TVP and I would not once see another member of my team while I was supposed to be onboarded.

Work Life Balance - This I feel would be rated highly on some peoples reviews due to the WFH option and flexible hours.... however it causes so many issues when everyone does this as no one works to the same schedule, so emails are sent 24/7 and you therefore really do not have a life as you are constantly getting asked questions and required to jump on something 24/7, you cannot just down tools and forget about work even at the weekends.

Communication - all done electronically and when you do get some face time everyone is far to busy to give you the time of day. diary's are not shared due to the god awful email client they use 

Self Service to the extreme - do not expect anything to be done the "old fashioned" way of talking with someone everything is electronic and you are expected to know who to contact and where it is on their vast intranet/s (they have several)

Onboarding - non existent 2 weeks of face time with colleagues in 3 months is not acceptable for a new starter, just give you a bunch of links and away you go. You are expected to make all of the meetings happen and onboard yourself without any guidance from management.

Ruthless - will do ANYTHING to get a sale and very clique old boys club

Promotion/Comp increase - from what I heard within the business not one of my team were promoted in 5 years and rises are 5% IF you get a promotion to the next grade.

Demographic - Full of oracle veterans that have been with the company for 5 years+ which is why there is such little change in what they do today compared to 10 years ago

review_title: Poor engineering culture
job_title: Senior Member Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros:
- Fairly relaxed work culture. You can work from home pretty much all the time. Also, some of the benefits in India - reimbursement for phone/broadband and quality of medical insurance coverage are pretty good compared to other companies. It's a good company to 'retire' or 'park' yourself for a while, if your personal circumstances require that.
- In the right team, work can be challenging and rewarding
cons:
- Note that I said 'in the right team'. I should add: under the right management. I re-orged from under a fairly good manager with so-so, not so challenging work to a team with a terrible manager and the same kind of work.  In the team I was in(and I've seen this in other groups too), the best work was done in the US, and only grunt work is sent to India. 

- Even in the good teams, engineering culture is quite poor. Coming from an Oracle 'competitor' in the enterprise software space, I was shocked at just how poor coding standards, code review practices and development at Oracle was overall. You get to work on marquee products which solve challenging technological problems, but it feels like stuff is held together with duct tape. Features are released without real QA, QA teams are understaffed and under skilled (the 'automation' QA teams write would be laughed at in other companies), and customer deployments act as default QA. Middle managers play the blame game quite well, getting enough of the blame shifted elsewhere.
- Compensation increases are poor. Hikes/bonuses are low or non-existent, so negotiating well while joining is a good strategy. India is seen as a 'low-cost' development centre, and cost cutting in terms of budgets is visible quite often. The contrast to competitors for both business and engineers (Microsoft, NetApp, VMWare) wrt these things is glaring. 
- Decision making including approvals for exceptional expenses (e.g. new devices for mobile testing) can take months, if not a year or more since everything goes up to at least a VP in the US.
- I did not attempt to change teams in my time there, but was also heavily advised against it, with at least one veteran saying "It's career suicide".

review_title: “Strong positives, strong negatives ”
pros: It's a big company, and it varies quite a bit by job/org, but... - Great work environment, with lots of good people who are working hard. If you want to excel, go somewhere else. - Onboarding process is a joke. Most jobs have no training, because no one is in charge of training. - Along those lines, if it isn't assigned to someone, it doesn't get done. Oracle is like the former USSR--centrally planned, with only a chosen few making decisions, and endless bureacracy for everyone else. It is the opposite of an empowering culture.

review_title: Think and judge before you Join!!!
pros:
I am working with Oracle for almost an year now, into Flexcube Consulting Division.
For me, working with OFSS (oracle Financial Services Software ltd.) is not upto the mark what i assumed before joining here.
few Pointers which I would like to highlight:

1. will find many veterans serving the company for 10, 15 and even 25 years too, and don't foresee to move anywhere else and mayn't be preferred by few employers due to change adaptation issues.
2. people here from i-flex time (before Oracle took over), and now they know in-out of flexcube and happy to stay. If you gather similar experience in another 3-4 years would enjoy staying. but I prefer to move fast with market.
3. Job security is very high, and almost null chances you will be fired.
4. Anyone joins will be able to sharpen a lot in banking processes and will be a great learning indeed.
5. People who like to stay low and just want job security with same salary for years and no pain on unbalanced work life... Can join.
cons:
Few genuine Cons I would like to highlight:

1. Onsite travel is almost reduced except some alien African regions you will be pushed to travel. Other regions already a long queue is waiting to travel and if you join any soon will have to wait min. 2-3 years to get a chance.
2. Onsite travel is done on actual, so any though of saving with per-dimes is totally out now.
3. Work life balance is quite negative, especially when the Flexcube deliverable are not matching with clients expectations and you have to really slog for hours and every weekend w/o any comp-off for months. This is not only for my team but applies to almost every regional team.
4. No Pay hike for many years and even if that happens would not be more than 10% in every 2-3 years. So judge whats average growth per year.
5. Bonus people may get 80 to full, twice a year in pro-rated value, provided you are fully mapped into any project for 365 days else if in bench or resource pool then may get just 20% of your variables.
6. no matter how smart you are, from where you have come in, how good in certain skills you are... you are bound to work the way its been working for ages and no skill developments.
7. HR dept, sorry but I hope it exists.
8. I am not unhappy with OFSS, rather the reason I might move on, is because I don't see any future in a long run, where industry demands more varied experience, and only my flexcube experience is not going to run the miles for me anymore, as market has now many competitive Core banking applications other than Flexcube, like Finacle, Temenos, Bancs, SAP etc.
9. the most important, this is not a flat organization. So if you are not accustomed to say Sir & Madam then keep away, else never know whose egoistic emotions get hurt badly.

review_title: Not at All good for a fresher

review_title: The Leviathan Strikes Again!
pros: The company is very large. If you're seeking job security, chances are you'll find it here due to the massive government/enterprise contracts. This also means that it's possible to pivot while staying inside the company.
cons:
The company is very large. Unless you're in a situation where you crave stability and a relatively low-impact work schedule (e.g., parent), you'll probably get bored pretty quickly. In addition, I've heard from some colleagues that sticking around at Oracle for too long can look bad in some quarters. Keep that in mind if you feel like you'll want to get a new job later.

In addition, companies they buy out tend to fall apart pretty quickly. I worked for a company that was humming along quite nicely until it was bought out. Within a year of the merger completion, well over half of the key employees who helped shape the company or were rock stars within the company had quit to form their own companies or join other companies. (Some quit right at a year. I'm guessing they were offered large bonuses if they stuck around for a year.) The only people left were, in general, those who couldn't be bothered to move on. I'm not saying the remaining employees were idiots. I'm just saying that things slowed down rapidly due to the sudden turnover, with little exciting work coming in.

Finally, Oracle's vacation policy is awful. I had three weeks paid vacation and unlimited sick time, and was about to go up to four weeks paid vacation when Oracle took it all away. They only offered 2 1/2 weeks of paid vacation, along with two fewer observed holidays and limited sick leave. So, they basically took away over a week of vacation time. At least they counted time at the old company towards time at Oracle.

review_title: Acquired as part of the Oracle-MICROS takeover. Resigned in frustration
pros: Good benefit scheme, possibility to relocate globally, huge diverse workforce, ability to progress through the ranks and an organised corporate structure.
cons: Oh boy where to start. . .  Micros was acquired under Oracle's banner of 'embrace the change' and 'this is a great opportunity for you all.' Should have read between the lines and understood that they are just a bunch of liars. Within 6 months it became apparent that we would likely never get another salary increment, that there would be no new hires in our office and that the UK/IRL support new hires would be done in Romania where all the knowledge and talent are not. While we witnessed this happening (in front of our eyes no less) the good people at Oracle never communicated one iota of this to us. Au contraire, they still persisted with the fantasy that everything was wonderful. Slowly over time, most of our experienced and highly skilled support staff just melted away as they got fed up with a rising workload and did not care to try and find alternate employment within a company that had been so deceitful. Whatever MICROS was like to work for, they at least knew how to support their products and ensure their customers incidents were progressed in a timely manner. Oracle Hospitality has failed in this aspect so spectacularly that it almost seems like it was done willingly.

review_title: A Big Machine
pros:
Local management is as good as industry average or better. Benefits (except holidays) are pretty good. Work is interesting and the team I worked with was good.
Free soda and  coffee. The cafeteria is pretty good also.
cons:
The Oracle culture does not believe in the worth of individual employees. They are looking for cogs who should be kept in the dark and protected from anyone trying to recruit you. 
Oracle does not believe in all-hands meetings. Oracle's internal email about quarterly results is laughably propagandistic - you need to look at external sources to see how they really were, even if they were relatively good. Oracle people are strongly discouraged from participating in external technical activities. 
When Mark Hurd got hired by Larry Ellison after being fired by HP for lying on expense reports (and after Larry laughing at HP for caring) we got an email from HR telling us that we, the lackeys, shouldn't lie on ours. Hilarious. 
When they shifted top management around, so Larry was no longer CEO, we never even got email about it. 
When they decided to force most employees to take vacation between Christmas and New Years, instead of being honest about this being good for the bottom line, the mail was about how lucky we were to be forced to take this time off. Contrast to Sun, which was honest about forcing a July 4th  week off. 
Sun had lots of internal mail and awards programs for the average employee. Oracle has none. (I think they started featuring a few HR people.) 
Oracle has a pay system which gives all the money to the top tier and nothing to anyone else. The average employee is a lot better than that - and there is a pretty rigorous interview process. After a few years of this they noticed that people were not staying late anymore. And got outraged. Wonder why? My boss, to his credit, could hardly keep himself from cracking up at the email telling us how bad we were for leaving early. 
I'm dubious about the future of this company - it is not well likes in the industry. I avoided Oracle stock and I'm glad I did. Good software people should head for Google or Facebook. 
That Larry blew off a keynote at Oracle World to watch his yacht race in the America's Cup says it all about top management.

review_title: Application Sales Manager
job_title: Applications Sales Manager in Houston, TX
pros:
1. Autonomy in day to day management of my efforts
2. Very good benefits
3. Comprehensive product portfolio

cons:
1. Very political internally.  So many pillars competing for budget dollars often had different teams working against eachother with the customer often the victim
2. Quarter to quarter life in sales.  No overt pressure to do the wrong thing for a customer but tons of pressure to make your number.  Reasonable but depending on patch, it can be an impossible challenge and the sales team is set up to churn not nurture.  A lot depends on your manager and product pillar which changed a lot while I was there over 4 years.
3. High pressure.  There is a lot of responsibility on the sales guy back
4. For me, the negatives were stressful but also sickeningly  fun at some level.  Not sure how to really explain that.  If you have a thick skin and sometimes enjoy the friction, it can be fun to manage this stuff.
5. In 2015, culture and focus at Oracle began to shift with major changes in product strategy which totally emphasized the cloud Saas Apps.  While I agree with the long-term goal, the implementation in the sales team, especially BI where we had a fading product, made survival difficult in most pillars.  Huge turnover and incentive programs that removed a lot of the ways we were successful in the past. 
6.  Most of my customers hated Oracle and dealing with us.

review_title: Not the best job to start with

review_title: Good Insurance - No Raises
pros:
The vast majority of employees and first line managers I worked for we're very good people.  The kind you'd voluntarily grab a beer with after work.  It's a great spot to get your first job high tech. 

Note: This entire review is for a business role, not a technical role
cons:
I was with them for 2.5 years.  Even after being ranked in the top 10% of employees in my level / job description, for the I received no raise (and neither did the only other person on my team that had the highest score).  She didn't get an increase even over almost 3 years.  They hired fresh graduates at higher salaries than those of us who had 5+ years of experience, and had been with Oracle for a couple years.  Especially those who started careers at the height of the recession.

Oracle wont pay you what you're worth until you tell them you have another offer.  It's apparently the only way to get a meaningful base salary adjustment, even with a great performance review.

My local management (up to Sr. Director) had no apparent ability to offer meaningful raises.  The SVP+ level left their hands pretty tied.  The one year my Sr. Director got a raise budget, it was something pathetic, like $20k to spread out over 120 employees.  That would work out to like an 8 cent per employee increase if he divided it equally.

Their internal systems are the worst in the industry.  I hope the version of DAS, e-Business Suite, etc. isn't the same version they sell people.  I didn't appreciate how slow and inefficient these systems were, until I went to work for a competitor.

Salaries are not "competitive" -- their comp philosophy is a "trailing" -- not "leading" one -- at least in the back-office business roles (attorneys, accountants, finance, etc. under Safra) I left for another large software company, and got almost a 3x increase in overall comp with bonus, stock, etc.

review_title: Toxic culture run amok with cloud collapse looming
pros: Decent pay on hire, but don't expect any increases after that.   Healthcare beneifits OK.  Lame match on 401K ...(vests over four years...ridiculous).  Some great smart dedicated folks staying on despite the suffering.
cons: Legacy  dominance hierarchy with toxic back-biting and infighting as execs compete to get more employees reporting to them (this is the only apparent criteria to promote execs used by the HR team).  Miss on business objectives has created massive pressure and ensuing neurotic/toxic behavior across teams, including departure of original cloud visionary.   Recent revisions to financial statement methods (to hide their failures?) adds distrust to already long list of why employees have zero faith and trust in management team.    Execs have been going thru the motions to convey shift to enlightened network-based culture, but it is all a ruse.   They quickly snap back to 'command and control' expectations for compliant employees who will salute the old (really old now) guard.    The miserable culture is made worse by a cacophony of old crap tools that are used only to manipulate people into meetings where managers can feel self-important, then supplement these with important, and always competiting, missives from all parts of the beaucracy vying for the latest "mandatory" training program to futher sap any remaining erergy or passion from the few remaining long-timers.   This company is HIRING a bunch!   Not because they are growing, but because their people are all leaving!

review_title: Oracle Data Cloud - what a mess
pros:
Unlimited PTO
Flexible work from home policy 
Some great products via acquisitions 
Good industry reputation and you partner with top agencies+brands, google, amazon, facebook, Snapchat, Pinterest, the trade desk, etc. 
good name on the resume for sales 
Great peers. a lot of nice, talented people below management
cons:
an absolute dumpster fire of a mess. The worst job I have ever had. I would avoid at all costs. 

the organization is very silo’ed. You have no visibility into what other teams are doing, leadership, product, etc. 

sales quotas created out of thin air. No data to back them and leadership takes in no input from the sales reps. the majority of the sales team appears to be far under their quota.

senior leadership is abhorrent (though we recently hired a new ceo who has a great background and seems smart, sensible, and like a good person). 

Many in sales leadership don’t have sales backgrounds. head of sales has never sold before. This leads to a fundamental misunderstanding of how to run a sales team, how to motivate, how to sell, who should sell what, how goals should be created, etc.
No idea how we are performing - aren’t given clear success metrics outside of our quota. We don’t know what our commission is going to be until it hits our bank account. Also commissions are consistently paid late. Some reps don’t get paid at all and managers will do little to help you collect. 
Teams aren’t regionalzied. People are just scattered throughout the country. Causes bad client interactions and a lack of accountability.
No CRM. This is especially bad because we have about five sales teams selling the same products to the same clients. Clients complain about this all the time. Creates confusion and tension internally and externally.
Zero onboarding and no product training. This results in feeling totally lost and overwhelmed when you start and costs the company money because onboarding takes so long. 
the worst and most disrespectful manager I have ever worked for. Offers zero help/guidance, micromanages, rarely in the office office, makes my job harder by putting roadblocks in my way.
- No culture. On our floor with roughly 150 desks, about 30 people show up daily. 
No raises. 
Sexual harassment and discrimination is prevalent. many older managers trying to date/hook up with nearly entry level employees. Seen some managers dating their subordinates. Many men talk down to the women - seen multiple women cry after getting yelled at. When asked about diversity the (former) ceo said he only hires talent not for diversity, which is ironic because he hired a head of sales who has never sold before. 
some massive pay disparities. I was paid about 100k more to do the same job as a female counterpart.  
Oracle specific problems - the email and calendar system is poor - have missed meetings with clients because my calendar doesn’t sync properly,  forced to delete emails in my inbox every 6 months because we have an email quota we can’t exceed, expenses take a gross amount of time which takes away from time you could be working, IT will not respond to your inquiries for help, zero software or tools to help you succeed.

review_title: Really love this company... but it makes me sick writing this review
job_title: Cloud Sales Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Amazing talent with amazing products!!  You cannot find another company where you can learn more, the resources are there, the experts are there... but you’ll need to figure out the internal systems, relationships, and your time management to take advantage. 
At its height, Oracle was doing 83 acquisitions/year. Sure integration was rocky, but it worked!!  You cannot beat this company’s organizational skills when you are looking on getting a deal done. Also, I remember going from 32,000 to 125,000 employees. Again, there were bumps but it happened fast and the effect to any one person was relatively not impactful. There isn’t another company that grew that fast in such a short amount of time, maintaining the profitability of Oracle, and with the breath of products the Oracle has to offer. I admire Larry Ellison for what he has done with Oracle, they remain the only company to offer the customer the full portfolio of products. I met some great people at Oracle, some who become some of my best friends.
cons:
I started working at Oracle in the mid-2000s. I was probably 1 out of 2 or 3 out of 50-70 reps in an area. For a few years, there was very little difference between myself and the men. As the company got larger, new players were introduced, I started becoming victim to sexual harassment. Being younger, with very little co-workers that were also female to potentially confide in and ask for direction, I kept quiet. As the years went on, more women joined the company. I started noting it wasn’t only happening to me, but to others and few said anything... yet these men were being promoted. In my last year, I ran into sexual discrimination. It wasn’t just me, I noticed the same manager was doing it to most female direct reports. I had heard about this happening with other teams, but never seen it personally... it was disgusting. HR turns a blind eye to sexual discrimination. The men get promoted in those situations as well, even in the #metoo era.  Keep in mind, I’m talking about a rather progressive thinking Silicon Valley TECH company NOT some 1920s or 1950s oil company. It was very disappointing, repulsive, frustrating, and demeaning. 
Women are constantly overlooked for the next best spot, whether it’s a territory or a managerial promotion. Due to the culture, if you are a woman and somehow land the next best spot, be aware that your team and everyone they speak to will be talking about how you got that spot!  IT DOESNT STOP!!

review_title: Okay if it's your first job.
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Austin, TX
pros:
You get to know some great people along the way. I found a lot of the Solutions Engineers to be extremely helpful, friendly, and always there for you.
You have free drinks and a nice gym with fitness classes, however, once you expand into what other companies offer (way smaller companies) it's not even that impressive.
cons:
Company culture is lacking. It seemed that every Class Of was mainly filled middle-upper class white folks and and times pretty much a sorority/frat house. Given that everyone is fresh out of college you'll realize how much they talk about Greek life to the point that is sometimes annoying. 
The job is pretty straight forward but so many things will affect your performance. Metrics will most likely come to you late (if not the last day of the quarter). This is very depending on the  side of the business you are but in Cloud this is how things roll. 

Additionally, you have NO CREDIBILITY in the marketplace and customers will rant out about how much they hate Larry and rarely want to talk to you. If you have a good territory things may be easier but only as good as the Account Manager (Rep) you're assigned and their willingness to work with you.  
I have only been given an achievement number in my first quarter in seat. I asked after that since I was applying for something internally and the managers failed to provide me with a final attainment number and asked me if I kept a record of the work so that  I could do the math. What is that? Because of that it's also extremely difficult to calculate your bonus and provide exact numbers to future employers.
There are a lot of other people calling into the same accounts as you are and if you reach out (it's not that simple to know if they're already working in a deal with them) you might get roasted over email by these other sales reps, their managers, and even directors. 
The CRM used to track your daily interactions IS REALLY BAD. I wonder why they wouldn't implement something like Salesforce but there are daily problems and bugs with it. Sometimes it has has been down for hours without being able to do anything and the support chat is almost useless all the time.
My overall experience since Oracle created a designated sales force to sell Cloud is that high-ups have failed to deliver to upper management and is having repercussions on us. They seem to try to change the game every quarter and implement new things to help boost sales and all have failed.
Venturing into other lines of businesses for promotion purposes is not straight-froward. The company wants you to be a BDC and then transition into an Account  Manager which as of 2019 has become A LOT more competitive since people used to get promoted based on time with the company and not qualifications.

review_title: Great place for a job not a career
job_title: Service Delivery Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Flexible work practices. 
Ability to work independently and autonomously. 
Exposure to great technology and some very smart people. 
Excellent benefits package and great brand recongition on your resume.
cons:
Lack of career growth opportunities promotion opportunities come as a result of filling deadmens shoes.
Management are not people centric revenue generation

review_title: Cheap Pay, Good Work

cons:
Salary is well below industry standard. Chances of significant salary increases are nil.  Employees are not rewarded well enough. Effort to retain good talent is negligible.  The overall message the company seems to send its employees is "we don't care. Stay if you like, if not we will just outsource your job to India."

In some groups managers are terrible, especially the ones with non-American Origin. I lost most of my hair working at one such group.

review_title: Like it or leave it.

Work/life balance.   
I respect the overall business savvy of senior management, and their ability to steer the company in the right direction.   The senior management team is engaged and passionate, they are not just figure heads.

review_title: Lots of freedom and creativity, no real salary increases
pros: If you are looking for a company where you can use your creativity, professional drive, willingness to think out of the box, then Oracle is the right place. There are no limits to what you can achieve. Although there is internal competition, you can gain power and support by outperforming, for which you will get real recognition.
cons: Once you started, you'll never get a reasonable salary increase again, irrespective of promotions or anything else. At best you'll get inflationary compensation. You will however get good bonuses and in some cases stock options.

review_title: Great
pros: Extraordinary investment in R&D and leading edge solutions through internal investment as well as acquisitions like RightNow and Taleo and others
cons: Very intense work environment with a performance oriented culture.  Almost everyone needs to be relatively technical to keep up with their managers and the rest of the team.

review_title: Great Company, but not in India
pros:
- Flexible work hours
- Access to technology. Can train yourself on pretty much anything.
- Decent pay package
cons:
- Mostly low end jobs get shipped to India. Most India teams are directionless
- No career growth for people with 5+ years of experience. You hit a glass ceiling soon. Performance appraisal process is a joke.
- Completely dominated and micromanaged from US. Indian leaders are mere administrators

review_title: Flexibility for work environment but a big machine to work for.
pros:
A lot of flexibility about where you work. 
Fairly stable. 
Lots of resources. 
Name recognition.
cons: The place is huge and more like a machine than a company. You have to like the group you are in, the manager you have, and the work you do in order to be happy here. You're not going to change the world at Oracle.  And there is a process for everything. Lots of dead weight in the company. It's not clear to me yet whether strong performers really get ahead of the dead weight.

review_title: Awesome Foundation for Learning Enterprise Software Technology!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
I worked at World Wide Headquarters in Redwood Shores, California (The Emerald City).  Opportunity to use Oracle University to develop knowledge about enterprise technology.  The company has enough business unit scale such that making lateral or vertical changes in career is possible.  

Acquisition of core technologies from other companies provides added opportunities to learn something new and applicable to industry.  Pay commensurate with level of entry into the business and previous experience - however, as is the case with most all enterprise software companies, Sales produces some of the biggest rewards in terms of annual compensation.

When I worked at Oracle, the culture was rich and diverse ethnically, hard-working professionally and fairly relaxed physically.  There was a restaurant on the ground floor of almost every building on the campus back then - not sure if that remains the case.  The food was tasty (not five star by any means) and you never had to leave the campus for much of anything throughout the day, unless you wanted to.  I ate breakfast before work on the ground floor of building 4 almost each day.

Great place for young talent to begin a career in enterprise software and equally a great place for seasoned and experience veterans to finish a career in enterprise software.  There aren't very many enterprise software companies that I can say that I would not mind having the opportunity to retire from, but outside of SAP, Oracle just might be that company!
cons:
Sometimes low to mid level management can be volatile in terms of turnover and change management can be somewhat overdone on internal procedures.  

Entry level salaries can be on the low-side, but well rounded employee benefits, on-site facilities, state of the art equipment, generous vacation and paid-time-off can help to buffer.

Depending on what you do and where you work, demand for output can be high - but you don't become a $6bln enterprise software company without high output somewhere - get used to it.

review_title: OK place to work, but little room for promotion, and raises/bonuses are few and far between

review_title: Oracle does everything. Have grown too big to manage.
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Pleasanton, CA
pros:

- Stable employer, flexibility.

- Salary is not at par with other similar companies in the SF bay area.
- Oracle has stopped sharing profits with employees since 2008 even though executives are paid very well. E.g. ORCL product dev EVP Thomas Kurian made USD 36 million last year (compare that to 25 million for GE CEO).

review_title: A lot of the coding is for internal integration
job_title: Consuling Member of Technical Staff in San Jose, CA
pros: Nice work life balance.  Few death marches to get the code out.  Nice people from different backgrounds.  Flexible work hours and flexible work locations.
cons: Difficult to get things changed.  The top priority is what drives managers bonus so everything else is ignored.  Guess what is the next top priority?  Difficult to make internal job transfers.

review_title: Excellent Work Life Balance
pros:
Great Work Life Balance
Flexible time - Work from home on need basis
Great learning opportunities - If you have the attitude
Quality Peers / Managers
Ownership 
Interacting with top customers of the world
cons:
Too bureaucratic
Too big. Individual contributors / Managers - Entry level and middle level - We are not significant in the overall scheme of things.
Expect low pay and compensation. The average guy don't get any increases for most years and some below par increases during other years. Good performers get very low raises / hikes.
Promotions will not get you an automatic hike.

review_title: Project Manager
pros: Great company to work for with very enjoyable & professional working relationships across all sectors of the organization, from the CEO to everyone in the Technology Center.   Most jobs are remote, work from home office with client travel for on-site requirements averaging 30 -50%.  Therefore, great work / life balance indeed.
cons: TOA gives a bit too much to their clients in the form of discounted pricing.  Should stand their ground with industry standard pricing as our product is far superior to any other WFM / Field Service software available.

review_title: Big company with great benefits, less meaningful work
job_title: Program Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Great benefits and stable progression. You knew what was coming as long you put your work in. Great transparency on promotions. Free gym and pool. Food was not free but still very good in the cafeteria. Flex time allowed to work at home or in the office. Remote work was actually preferred unless you wanted a desk. Company was very eco-minded.
cons: Work was not meaningful and you didn't get to see your individual contribution towards a larger picture. Thing took 2-3 weeks to turnaround which is typical for a company of this size.

review_title: Life here at Oracle
pros:
Great mix of talented people
Job challenge depends upon your own commitment
Benefits are competitive
cons:
Little to no pay raises over the last 5 years
Vacation time is stuck at 18 days max in the US
Stock options for employees not in management are minimal

review_title: Laid back culture with work-life imbalance, imbalance on the side of life
pros: It all depends on your team but in general I have found that for a reasonable competent person the work is very less stressful. In the beginning there is a learning curve involved but after an year or so there is nothing much to learn and the tasks that earlier took hours would only take minutes. As long as you can delegate the low level work (more below) your work days are very short. Of-course you would have to attend the meetings!
cons: Limited to no growth opportunities.

review_title: Great earning potential and benefits, but you are just a number.
pros: High salaries and great benefits which make a difference to your work/life balance.
cons:
- You are just a number at Oracle. If you do well you won't generally be recognised by many people. If the rest of the team didn't perform well you pretty much become disliked. Strange culture.
- If you want a promotion you basically have to invite the right people to go to lunch with you on a regular basis so you can 'network' and get 'advice'.

review_title: Big Enterprise
job_title: Senior Software Development Manager in New York, NY
pros: Recognized name, good benefits, nice office, corporate discounts, great location, the projects you are building will be used by millions of people.
cons: Too heavy-weight processes (waterfall), too many levels of management (11), outdated development tools; hard to make a differenece; you will have to follow established rules even if you know how to do things better; compensation is lower than competitors'.

review_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff
pros:
Great campus at HQ.
Flexibility.
Lot of scope to learn new technology.
cons:
Promotions for individual contributors are rare after PMTS position.
If you need promotions from time to time, the only option is to become a manager.
So if you do not like to manage, be prepared to live a life with 2 or 3 promotions max.
Raises, bonus, stock etc are given to privileged few, while these things are dormant for the majority.

review_title: Principle Member Technical Staff
